history.content:
Since you've already taken math 54, you should have less trouble taking  ee16a. Even if you didn't fully understand everything when you first took linear algebra, you are still going into the class with a good amount of background information. EE16a is designed with no prior linear algebra knowledge in mind, so it will likely be less stressful for you than cs61c which would assumedly be all brand new concepts to you.

———-

Took that combo this semester with a breadth and CS370. EE16A has weekly problem sets which take anywhere from 4-10 hours, depending on how well you absorbed the material and on your ability to pattern match(applying the concept in lecture to the questions on the problem set). And cs61c has projects that are no joke and filled with information. I like 61c a lot though because it teaches you basically the intersection of hard ware and software on top of other seemingly random things like parallelism, threads, briefly networking and I/O, with some programming in C. Both manageable though and the circuits in 16a help you seduce why the hardware is a certain way so it helps with connecting the dots.

Since you've already taken math 54, you should have less trouble taking  ee16a. Even if you didn't fully understand everything when you first took linear algebra, you are still going into the class with a good amount of background information. EE16a is designed with no prior linear algebra knowledge in mind, so it will likely be less stressful for you than cs61c which would assumedly be all brand new concepts to you.

Linear algebra is pretty difficult for me (struggled to understand the latter half of Math 54). Coding relatively large lower div projects (Hilfinger 61b projects) has been pretty easy. Any suggestions on which class (EE16a vs 61c) would be lower workload for my case?
history.subject: EE16a vs 61c workload
